full.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: containing as much or as many things or people as possible, so there is no space left
full.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Don’t talk with your mouth full.
The class is full, but you can register for next term.
The bath was full to the brim (=completely full) with hot water.
Ted’s workshop was crammed full of old engines.
be crammed/stuffed/packed etc full of something
McQuaid filled his glass until it was three-quarters full.
The filing cabinet was full to bursting.
The kitchen was full of smoke.
full.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people often say that a place is packed when it is full of people:
The trains are always packed in the rush hour.
full.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: complete and including all parts or details
full.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Please write your full name and address on the form.
The Health Centre offers a full range of services.
Lotus will not reveal full details until the Motor Show.
The BBC promised a full investigation.
I don’t think he’s telling us the full story (=everything he knows about the matter).
full.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the greatest amount or highest level of something that is possible
full.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The charity helps disabled children reach their full potential.
Few customers take full advantage of off-peak fares.
Parker was driving at full speed when he hit the wall.
The roses were now in full bloom.
full.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: having eaten so much food that you cannot eat any more
full.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: used to emphasize an amount, quantity, or rate
full.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: We devote five full days a month to training.
His pants rose a full three inches off his shoes.
full.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: busy and involving lots of different activities
full.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Before her illness, Rose enjoyed a full life.
Go to bed. You’ve a full day tomorrow.
full.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: having or giving all the rights, duties etc that belong to a particular rank or position
full.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Only full members have the right to vote.
full.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: made using a lot of material and fitting loosely
full.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: a dress with a full skirt
full.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: large and rounded in an attractive way
full.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: Now you can enjoy Nescafé's fuller flavour in a decaffeinated form.
full.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: the rich full sound of the cello
full.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: full
containing as much or as many things or people as possible, so there is no space left
The train was nearly full.
The cupboard was full of clothes.
He spilled a full cup of coffee on the carpet.
filled with something
full of something – use this about a container when a lot of things have been put into it
The envelopes were filled with cash.
stuffed full of something
completely full of something – use this about a container when lots of things have been put into it, often in an untidy way
The case was stuffed full of clothes.
packed
completely full of people – use this about a room, train etc
a packed restaurant
The courtroom will be packed with journalists.
bursting (with something)
extremely full of something
Her wardrobe was bursting with coats and shoes.
a small garden bursting with fruit and flowers
crammed
so full that you cannot fit anyone or anything else in – often used when you think there are too many people or things
In summer, the hotels are crammed with tourists.
The resort’s crammed beaches are uncomfortable in summer.
teeming (with something)
full of people, animals etc that are all moving around
The rivers are teeming with fish.
overflowing
used about a container that is so full that the liquid or things inside it come out over the top
an overflowing bathtub
The drawers were overflowing with magazines.
overloaded
used about a vehicle or a ship which has too many people or things in it
an overloaded fishing boat
The trucks are often grossly overloaded (=far too overloaded).
full.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: She looked him full in the face as she spoke.
